physical_appearance:This is a batik altar cloth. It consists of two panels. The lower panel features a pair of phoenixes and three mythical qilins amidst cloud forms. Surrounding them are emblems such as a scroll and a vase. The top panel features eight figures amongst cloud forms. The panels are bordered by a floral scrolling pattern. There is a signature on the bottom-right of the altar cloth.

sgcool_label_text:A pair of phoenixes and three mythical qilins are shown on the lower panel of this tok wi or altar cloth.  On the upper panel are eight figures
 possibly depicting semi-divine Daoist Eight Immortals.  Surrouding the qilins and phoenixes on the lower panel are emblems of the Eight Immortals
 symbolising happiness and transmutation.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987)
 the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures
 she used her husband’s name
 Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards
 she used Jane Hendromartono
 combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name
 Hendromartono with Jane
 as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother
 and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds
 rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe
 America and Japan
 especially in the 1980s.  This piece is signed “Jane Hendromartono ‘77”.

metadata.sgcool_label_text: A pair of phoenixes and three mythical qilins are shown on the lower panel of this tok wi or altar cloth.  On the upper panel are eight figures, possibly depicting semi-divine Daoist Eight Immortals.  Surrouding the qilins and phoenixes on the lower panel are emblems of the Eight Immortals, symbolising happiness and transmutation.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987), the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures, she used her husband’s name, Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards, she used Jane Hendromartono, combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name, Hendromartono with Jane, as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother, and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds, rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe, America and Japan, especially in the 1980s.  This piece is signed “Jane Hendromartono ‘77”.
